Ban Bitcoin mining to save the environment, say Swedish authorities10/12/2021

Environment and finance regulators in the Nordic country say crypto mining's electricity usage is putting the climate at risk.

Paris agreement on climate, Bitcoin, Sweden, cryptocurrency, Climate crisis, COP26, next_moneyRead

     title="Swedish financial and environmental regulators want to ban Bitcoin mining in the EU because of its environmental impact" alt="Swedish financial and environmental regulators want to ban Bitcoin mining in the EU because of its environmental impact" width="320" height="180"></div></div></div></div><div class="c-article-media-copyright u-margin-top-1 "><span class="c-caption">
    Swedish financial and environmental regulators want to ban Bitcoin mining in the EU because of its environmental impact
</span>
                              -  
                            <span class="c-copyright"><span class="c-copyright__label">Copyright</span> 
        <a class="c-copyright__link" href="#">Pawel Czerwinski / Unsplash</a></span></div><div class="c-article__container jsBottomArticle"><div class="u-show-for-medium"></div><div class="js-responsive-iframes-container"><div class="o-article__body__container u-margin-x-auto"><div class="u-margin-bottom-3 u-margin-top-3 u-margin-x-0 u-margin-top-medium-4 u-margin-top-xlarge-5"><div class="c-article-contributors">
          By <a target="_blank" rel="noopener" href="https://twitter.com/tomb8man"><b>Tom Bateman</b></a><time class="c-article-date" data-timestamp="1636720054" datetime="2021-11-12"><span class="c-article-date__bullet">  •  </span><span class="c-article-date__last-updated-label">Updated:</span> 12/11/2021
    </time></div></div><div class="c-article-content c-article-content--next js-article-content "><div class="c-article-content__first-element"></div><p>Faced with a sharp rise in energy consumption, Swedish authorities are calling on the European Union to ban "energy intensive" crypto mining.</p><div class="u-show-for-small-only"><div class="enw-MPU u-min-height-270"><div data-ad-name="adzone-mpu" data-ad-index="1" class="enw-MPU__img advertising js-adzone"></div></div></div><p>Erik Thedéen, director of the Swedish Financial Supervisory Authority, and Björn Risinger, director of the Swedish Environmental Protection Agency, said cryptocurrency's rising energy usage is threatening Sweden's ability to meet its obligations under the Paris Climate Agreement.</p><p>Between April and August this year, the energy consumption of Bitcoin mining in the Nordic country rose "several hundred per cent," and now consumes the equivalent electricity of 200,000 households, Thedéen and Risinger said.</p><div class="c-advertising-sticky-floor"><div data-ad-name="adzone-sticky-floor" 
        data-ad-index="0"  
        class="advertising advertising--no-label js-adzone"></div><button class="c-advertising-sticky-floor__btn-close" type="button" aria-label="Close advertising" onclick="this.parentElement.classList.add('u-hide-for-all')"><svg class="c-advertising-sticky-floor__btn-close__svg" width="10" height="10" viewBox="0 0 17 17" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="m16.6 15-6.5-6.5 6.4-6.5c0.4-0.4 0.4-1.2 0-1.6s-1.2-0.4-1.6 0l-6.4 6.5-6.5-6.5c-0.4-0.4-1.2-0.4-1.6 0s-0.4 1.2 0 1.6l6.5 6.5-6.6 6.5c-0.4 0.4-0.4 1.2 0 1.6s1.2 0.4 1.6 0l6.5-6.5 6.5 6.5c0.4 0.4 1.2 0.4 1.6 0 0.5-0.4 0.5-1.2 0.1-1.6z"/></svg></button></div><div data-ad-name="adzone-outstream" class="advertising advertising--no-label js-adzone outstream"></div><p>In an open letter, the directors of Sweden's top financial and environmental regulators called for an EU-wide ban on "proof of work" cryptocurrency mining, for Sweden to "halt the establishment" of new crypto mining operations and for companies that trade and invest in crypto assets to be prohibited from describing their business activities as environmentally sustainable.</p><h2>Proof of work</h2><p>The key issue driving the Swedish regulators' intervention is the "proof of work" system used to mint many cryptocurrencies including Bitcoin and Ether, the world's two largest tokens.</p><div data-stories-id="6071846,6111824" data-event="widget_related" class="widget widget--type-related widget--size-fullwidth widget--align-center"><div class="widget__wrapper"><div class="widget__ratio widget__ratio--auto"><div class="widget__contents"><ul class="widget__related_list"><li class="widget__related_listItem"><a href="https://www.euronews.com/next/2021/09/15/bitcoin-uses-more-power-in-2021-than-all-of-2020-as-climate-debate-on-crypto-mining-heats-">Bitcoin used more power in 2021 than all of 2020 as climate debate on crypto mining heats up</a></li><li class="widget__related_listItem"><a href="https://www.euronews.com/next/2021/09/29/europe-is-now-the-world-s-cryptocurrency-capital">Europe is now the world's cryptocurrency capital as China's Bitcoin bans start to bite</a></li></ul></div></div></div></div><p>Under the proof of work system, computers must solve mathematical puzzles in order to validate transactions that occur on a given network.</p><p>The process is designed to become more difficult as the number of blocks of validated transactions in the chain increases, meaning more computing power - and therefore energy - is required.</p><div class="advertising advertising--no-label advertising--sharethrough js-adzone" data-ad-name="adzone-sharethrough" data-ad-index="1" data-ad-key="strnativekey" data-ad-key-value="1G96EdRgcHV6pyWWMGCR7SB7"></div><p>This leads to an arms race among miners, who compete to be the first to validate a new block and claim the prize of a new crypto coin: the more powerful your hardware, the more likely you are to get the coin.</p><h2>44 times around the world</h2><p>In recent months, the Nordic countries have seen a rise in crypto mining as producers attracted by lower energy prices and a relative abundance of renewable electricity flee China's crackdown on the industry.</p><p>The growth of crypto mining brings with it an opportunity cost, Thedéen and Risinger said, as Sweden's renewable energy is diverted away from industrial, transport and domestic uses, and into Bitcoin and other tokens.</p><div data-stories-id="6183662,5400906" data-event="widget_related" class="widget widget--type-related widget--size-fullwidth widget--align-center"><div class="widget__wrapper"><div class="widget__ratio widget__ratio--auto"><div class="widget__contents"><ul class="widget__related_list"><li class="widget__related_listItem"><a href="https://www.euronews.com/green/2021/11/03/could-renewable-energy-help-bitcoin-clean-up-its-carbon-footprint">Will Bitcoin survive without a shift to renewable energy?</a></li><li class="widget__related_listItem"><a href="https://www.euronews.com/next/2021/10/29/volcanic-energy-is-creating-bitcoin-in-el-salvador">Volcanoes are being harnessed to power Bitcoin mining in El Salvador in this new pilot project</a></li></ul></div></div></div></div><p>"It is currently possible to drive a mid-size electric car 1.8 million kilometres using the same energy it takes to mine one single Bitcoin,” they said.</p><p>“This is the equivalent of forty-four laps around the globe. 900 bitcoins are mined every day. This is not a reasonable use of our renewable energy".</p><div class="ads small-12 column text-center show-for-small-only u-show-for-small-only"><div class="enw-MPU "><div data-ad-name="adzone-mpu" data-ad-index="2" class="enw-MPU__img advertising js-adzone"></div></div></div><p>Euronews Next has contacted the Swedish, Norwegian and Icelandic environment ministries and the European Commission to ask whether or not they support the call to ban proof of work mining.</p></div><div class="clear"></div></div></div></div><div class="c-article__container"><div class="u-show-for-medium"></div><footer readabilityObject.title: Ban Bitcoin mining to save the environment, say Swedish authorities
readabilityObject.content:
Faced with a sharp rise in energy consumption, Swedish authorities are calling on the European Union to ban "energy intensive" crypto mining.

Erik Theden, director of the Swedish Financial Supervisory Authority, and Bjrn Risinger, director of the Swedish Environmental Protection Agency, said cryptocurrency's rising energy usage is threatening Sweden's ability to meet its obligations under the Paris Climate Agreement.

Between April and August this year, the energy consumption of Bitcoin mining in the Nordic country rose "several hundred per cent," and now consumes the equivalent electricity of 200,000 households, Theden and Risinger said.

In an open letter, the directors of Sweden's top financial and environmental regulators called for an EU-wide ban on "proof of work" cryptocurrency mining, for Sweden to "halt the establishment" of new crypto mining operations and for companies that trade and invest in crypto assets to be prohibited from describing their business activities as environmentally sustainable.

Proof of work

The key issue driving the Swedish regulators' intervention is the "proof of work" system used to mint many cryptocurrencies including Bitcoin and Ether, the world's two largest tokens.

Under the proof of work system, computers must solve mathematical puzzles in order to validate transactions that occur on a given network.

The process is designed to become more difficult as the number of blocks of validated transactions in the chain increases, meaning more computing power - and therefore energy - is required.

This leads to an arms race among miners, who compete to be the first to validate a new block and claim the prize of a new crypto coin: the more powerful your hardware, the more likely you are to get the coin.

44 times around the world

In recent months, the Nordic countries have seen a rise in crypto mining as producers attracted by lower energy prices and a relative abundance of renewable electricity flee China's crackdown on the industry.

The growth of crypto mining brings with it an opportunity cost, Theden and Risinger said, as Sweden's renewable energy is diverted away from industrial, transport and domestic uses, and into Bitcoin and other tokens.

"It is currently possible to drive a mid-size electric car 1.8 million kilometres using the same energy it takes to mine one single Bitcoin, they said.

This is the equivalent of forty-four laps around the globe. 900 bitcoins are mined every day. This is not a reasonable use of our renewable energy".

Euronews Next has contacted the Swedish, Norwegian and Icelandic environment ministries and the European Commission to ask whether or not they support the call to ban proof of work mining.
